Leber congenital amaurosis (LCA) is a rare eye disorder that primarily affects the retina, which is the specialized tissue at the back of the eye that detects light and color. 2. People with LCA typically have severe visual impairment beginning in infancy. The visual impairment tends to be stable, although it may worsen very slowly over time. 3. LCA is associated with other vision problems, including an increased sensitivity to light (photophobia), involuntary movements of the eyes (nystagmus), and extreme farsightedness (hyperopia). 4. Affected individuals may also have what's known as strabismus, a misalignment or crossing of the eyes. 5. In addition to visual problems, people with LCA may have other health issues, including neurological problems such as seizures, mental retardation, and autism. 6. It's also possible to have LCA together with more common vision problems, such as myopia (nearsightedness) and astigmatism (an irregularly shaped cornea). 7. Infants with LCA typically have very poor vision and may not even recognize their parents. As children, they may learn to navigate the environment by using other senses and by memorizing the location of objects. 8. Most people with LCA have a good understanding of language, although they may have difficulty with speech and hearing. 9. People with LCA generally have normal intelligence, but learning disabilities and mental retardation are possible.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v5: 1. Leber congenital amaurosis (LCA) is an inherited eye disorder that appears at birth or in the first few months of life. It affects the retina, which is the specialized tissue at the back of the eye that detects light and color. 2. People with LCA have severe visual impairment beginning in infancy. They may not be able to see at all or see only shades of gray. 3. The visual impairment tends to be stable, although it may worsen very slowly over time. Other features of LCA include abnormalities of the eye's pupil, which may appear larger or smaller than normal, and a lack of response to light. 4. Nystagmus, or eye movements that jerk back and forth, may also occur. 5. The eye's clear front covering (cornea) may be cone-shaped and abnormally thin, a condition known as keratoconus. 6. In rare cases, LCA can be associated with other features, including mental retardation, psychiatric disorders, and a movement disorder similar to Parkinson's disease. 7. In most cases, LCA is caused by mutations in one of three genes. The gene responsible determines the specific symptoms a person will have. 8. Most people with LCA are born to parents with normal vision. When both parents have normal vision, the condition is referred to as autosomal recessive. 9. When LCA is caused by mutations in one of the three genes, the disorder is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. In autosomal dominant inheritance, only one copy of the gene needs to be changed for a person to have the condition. In most cases, people with an autosomal dominant form of LCA have no family history of the disorder. 10. The diagnosis of LCA is based on a combination of clinical features and genetic testing. There is no cure for LCA. Treatment may include specialized low-vision devices, such as magnifying glasses or telescopes, to improve vision.

Russell-Silver syndrome (RSS) is a genetic disorder characterized by low birth weight, slow growth, weak muscles (hypotonia), and a specific pattern of physical abnormalities. 2. The most common features of Russell-Silver syndrome are a small and thin body and limbs with a relatively large head, and a small jaw (micrognathia). 3. Other common features include a small, triangular face, down-slanting eyes, and a small, wide nasal bridge. 4. Individuals with Russell-Silver syndrome may have a single crease across the palm of their hand instead of the normal two, and may have more folds of skin on the back of their neck (increased skin folds on neck). 5. Russell-Silver syndrome is also associated with a higher risk of developing some medical conditions, including Wilms tumor (a kidney tumor), neurologic problems, and developmental delay. 6. Russell-Silver syndrome is caused by changes in a specific gene (TCF2) which is located on the long (q) arm of chromosome 11. 7. The TCF2 gene encodes for a transcription factor (protein that controls the expression of other genes) involved in regulating cell growth and development. 8. Russell-Silver syndrome is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. Autosomal dominant inheritance means that one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder. 9. In most cases, an affected person has one parent with the condition. 10. People with Russell-Silver syndrome are at risk for passing on the condition to their children. 11. Diagnosis. Diagnosis of Russell-Silver syndrome is based on the symptoms and physical examination. 12. Genetic testing can confirm the diagnosis, but genetic testing is not routinely available. 13. Russell-Silver syndrome is not associated with any specific treatment. Treatment is directed at the individual symptoms. 14. Prognosis. Russell-Silver syndrome is not associated with any specific complications or health problems. 15. People with Russell-Silver syndrome typically have normal intelligence and lifespan.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1. Recovery from stroke is a dynamic process that includes recovery of function at a site of brain damage as well as compensation for lost function through the use of alternative neural pathways and strategies. 2. The extent and time course of recovery after stroke depend on the size and location of the brain lesion, the degree of collateral damage, the rapidity of thrombolytic or neuroprotective intervention, the presence of coexisting brain damage, and the patient's age and previous physical and intellectual status. 3. The most complete recovery from a stroke occurs when the ischemia is caused by a transient insult, such as a thrombotic event, and no permanent brain damage has occurred. 4. The least complete recovery occurs when there is extensive infarction of brain tissue, as might occur with a cerebral embolism or hemorrhage. 5. The potential for compensation is greatest in the young and less in the elderly, in whom cerebral coex and neocortex are affected, and in whom there is a greater likelihood of permanent brain damage. 6. The potential for recovery is also reduced in the presence of coexisting Alzheimer disease, vascular dementia, or other degenerative disorders.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: 80% of stroke patients regain some or all of their functional ability.

PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: 1. Numbness and tingling sensations in the lower right arm could be due to a condition called carpal tunnel syndrome. 2. This condition occurs when the median nerve, which runs from the elbow to the hand, is compressed or irritated. 3. Some common risk factors for this condition include diabetes, obesity, repetitive wrist work, and thyroid problems. 4. Symptoms include numbness, tingling, and pain or weakness in the hand. 5. Treatment options include rest, wrist splints, steroid injections, and surgery.
